description: Credit card transaction fraud detection dataset covering 2019-01-01 to 2020-03-10. Contains 1,048,575 transactions from cardholders across the US, with a fraud rate of 0.5728%. 14 merchant categories and 51 US states represented.

trans_date_trans_time.note: Day-first format — NOT month-first. Use strptime('%d-%m-%Y %H:%M') to parse.

cc_num.note: Use as string key/identifier only — do NOT cast to int, sum, or compute on. Cannot be parsed as a normal integer.

merchant.note: All names start with 'fraud_' as a naming convention ONLY — this prefix is NOT a fraud indicator. Use the is_fraud column exclusively for fraud detection.

amt.note: Non-negative float. Use directly for arithmetic.

first.note: Personal identity information — avoid extracting or listing individual names in questions.

last.note: Personal identity information — avoid extracting or listing individual names in questions.

state.note: Includes DC. Always uppercase 2-letter codes, e.g. 'CA', 'NY', 'TX'.

zip.note: Stored as string to preserve leading zeros.

dob.note: Day-first format — NOT month-first. Use strptime('%d-%m-%Y') to parse.

trans_num.note: Use as unique key only — do not compute on.

unix_time.note: Can use datetime.fromtimestamp() or datetime.utcfromtimestamp() to convert.

is_fraud.note: 1 = fraudulent, 0 = legitimate. This is the ONLY field to use for fraud detection — do NOT use merchant name as a fraud signal.

merch_zipcode.note: Approximately 15% of rows have None/null. Always check: if row['merch_zipcode'] is not None before accessing.

dataset_keys.transactions: Stratified sample of 5000 transaction dicts with all 23 columns. Fraud rows overrepresented at ~20% for analytical utility. Use for cross-dimensional or per-transaction analysis.
dataset_keys.total_transactions: Integer count of all 1,048,575 rows in the full dataset
dataset_keys.total_fraudulent: Integer count of all 6,006 fraudulent rows in the full dataset
dataset_keys.fraud_rate: Overall fraud rate as float (0.005728) computed from all rows
dataset_keys.date_range: Dict with keys 'start' and 'end' as YYYY-MM-DD strings
dataset_keys.amount_distribution: Dict: min, max, mean, median, std, p25, p75, p95, p99 of transaction amounts (all rows)
dataset_keys.category_stats: Dict: category_name -> {count, total_amt, fraud_count, fraud_rate, avg_amt}. 14 categories, computed from all rows.
dataset_keys.state_stats: Dict: state_code -> {count, total_amt, fraud_count}. 51 US states, computed from all rows.
dataset_keys.top_merchants: List of top 20 merchants by count: [{merchant, count, total_amt, fraud_count, fraud_rate}]
dataset_keys.gender_breakdown: Dict: 'M' or 'F' -> {count, fraud_count, total_amt}, computed from all rows
dataset_keys.time_series: Dict: 'YYYY-MM' -> {count, total_amt, fraud_count}, monthly aggregates from all rows

important_notes: CRITICAL: All merchant names begin with 'fraud_' — naming convention only, NOT a fraud signal. Use is_fraud column only.
The transactions sample overrepresents fraud (~20%) vs real rate (~0.57%). Use pre-aggregated fields for global stats.
cc_num is in scientific notation as a string (e.g. '2.70319E+15') — treat as identifier only.
merch_zipcode has ~15% null values (Python None) — always handle None when iterating transactions.
trans_date_trans_time and dob are in DD-MM-YYYY format (day first, NOT month first).
Sandbox has no pandas/numpy. Use: list comprehensions, sum(), max(), min(), sorted(), collections.Counter, statistics, math.
